The Basement Collection... The price is awesome, especially for this much content. Let's take a look at the games:  Aether - Loved it, exploration game with some small puzzles. Controls could use some work, but this is a great concept. Could work in a standalone game.  Time Fc*k - Another great concept. Puzzle game where you switch between layers to solve puzzles. Could work in a standalone game.  Meat Boy - A classic! No controller support though (hard !! :().  Grey Matter - Shoot 'em up without the shooting. Wasn't all that impressed, but it's ok.  Coil - Something about a pregnant lady. Weird and the controls plain suck.  Triachnid - Again, the controls suck. And no saves so you have to restart the game every time you exit. Nice concept, terrible execution.  And then there's 2 secret games (one of them is AVGM which is all about mouse clicking, the other one is unknown as of now) and a whole lot of extra content (audio Q&A, artwork, etc.).  If you liked (S)MB and/or Isaac buy this !  [Rating: 80/100]

The price is about right. Lots of bonus content and quite a number of mini games. I'd say right away it's worth the money, especially since it's cheap. And as for most of this guy's games the music is great. Meat Boy is pretty terrible. If you thought Super Meat Boy was a pain, try imagine it with unresponsive controls. Triachnid is interesting but barely anything you'll play for long. Coil - Play a sperm! Aether is just kinda adorable and has you flinging through space. Not much to it but it's time well wasted. Time ♥♥♥♥ is probably the mechanically most interesting one, very much worth a try. Spewer is a great platformer with a nice look to it and good mechanics, but it maniacly pumps up the difficulty very suddenly. This is probably the most interesting of the games alongside Grey Matter... Which I can't really describe well, but it's quite a neat game.  The Basement Collection ain't much with much in it. Sounds strange, and rightfully so..... Til' next time.

While all of these games are available for free online, this collection is great for fans of Edmund McMillen. The special features are a nice insight into the twisted mind of the creator of Super Meat Boy, and it's always nice to support an indie developer.

Gameplay: Each game has its own unique feel, but consistently have tight and responsive controls.  Story: Most of the games are lacking a plot, but ocassionally have their own player-guided stories.  Graphics: The art style is more reminiscent of The Binding of Isaac than Super Meat Boy (previous games by the same developer), with various biblical references, hellish enemies and constant visually depicted black humour.  Sound: The soundtrack is great, catchy, interesting and fitting for each game.  Re-playability: There are lots of different games to unlock and heaps of extra content.

Did you enjoy The Binding of Isaac and Super Meat Boy? Did you enjoy any of these flash games when you played them online? Are you interested in learning more about Edmund McMillen -- the creative mind behind these games? If yes, then you should buy this, dummy. Sure the games are free online, but the extras are real nice and insightful, including bonus levels, Q&A, and cut Indie Game: The Movie footage.
This is a collection everyone should have in their basement.

As a long-time McMillen fan, I'm glad I have the oppurtunity to re-play these Flash classics- with extras. Time Kcfu is a fun, dimension-hopping puzzler; Spewer relies a bit more on your reflexes, with level design as delightful as Time Cufk; the original Meat Boy is an enjoyable demo of sorts to Super Meat Boy; Grey Matter is rather insubstansial, but still quick, twichy fun; Aether and Coil are interesting, moody interactive art-pieces (Aether being much more of a traditional game than Coil). The only game I don't particularly like is Tri-Achnid. Slow and clunky, not very fun to play. Altogether, more than worth four dollars. As a fan, the extras divulging the inspirations for the various titles and developer commentary were great, too.

While this set isn't quite as bad as '♥♥♥♥♥♥ controls the game' aka The Binding of Issac, I will say that most of these games are barely Newgrounds circa 2002 quality. Sure, most were created quicky, but I'm surprised at how badly the controls don't work in most of them. The best game, Time ♥♥♥♥, is VVVVV with level shifting instead of orientation swapping.   Is there some sort of rule that physics based Indie games must have really really terrible controls? Aether is a tedious rope swinging game that attempts to use rope physics to swing from planet to planet.   Coil was the last straw. Basically, according to the dialogue, you play as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥'s sperm as you violate a woman, impregnate her, and then drive the newborn? into despair during the formation of the fetus (how does that even work?). Oh, and the controls are crap.

If you're a fan of the developers of Binding of Isaac and Super Meat Boy, this is the game for you! If you're just a fan of the games themselves, this is *not* the game for you. It's a collection of scraps from earlier, ♥♥♥♥♥ier games that the devs made.   This is the sort of thing you'd expect to find as a 'bonus feature' on the Collector's Edition of Super Meat Boy or something. That's not the worst thing in the world! Just don't expect a new SMB or BoI. Just a lot of mediocre flash games and behind-the-scenes wackiness from the devs.
